edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:07): hehe
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:08): (a world in which specification writers walk as gods amongst men, perhaps? :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:08): it's called WHATWG
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:08): hopes the CSS WG transformed itself to a more WHATWG-like group in a non-hostile way
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:09): very diplomatic.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:10): I haven't been following what's going on closely enough but the CSS 2.1 spec certainly seems to have stalled. and it would be great if "CSS5" emerged from the CSS WG itself
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:10): I thought CSS 2.1 was supposed to be "CSS5"
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:11): in the sense of codifying existing behaviour and expectations
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:11): shame it just shrugs when it comes to table rendering of course, but that could be fixed...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:12): they seem to be mostly working on the spec and not on testing if it's correctly implemented and changing the spec if needed
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:12): the other problem, as Hixie indicated, is that little new stuff that is needed for web apps comes out of the CSS WG, if any
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:13): what is the solution?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:14): on a tangent, I've always thought that WHATWG is more fond of JavaScript than CSS
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:15): the WHATWG is focused on improving the semantic and logical side of the problem
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:15): there was hope that the CSS WG would solve the stylistic side but that hasn't happened yet
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:16): time to revive JSS perhaps? :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): there's also need for improving the underlying platforms, such as the DOM and HTTP and maybe the URL specs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): 73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642, I'm working on a new a version of the CSSOM

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:16): what seems alarming to me is that Hixie as a CSS WG insider says there's a problem and I had thought that the CSS WG was the best functioning WG at the W3C. (this may be an awfully naive though, but that's what I though)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): s/though/thought/
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:17): hard to define "best functioning" I guess
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:18): well, let's say the WG whose output had the most World Wide Web relevance
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:18): doesn't consider Web Services, private XML systems, Mobile Web and Semantic Web to have that much World Wide Web relevance.
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:18): ah, not the XQuery or RDF working groups, then :)
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:19): in that case, only HTML and CSS working groups would be relevant, yes?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:19): (and HTML was defunct until recently)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:20): 73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642: yes. (I was thinking of the pre-new HTML WG situation)
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:22): strange when you think of the importance of the web, that it's development is so anarchic
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:24): that's because if you want to move forward you need implementations
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:26): and no single vendor is responsible for the web
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:27): well, MSIE is mostly responsible for how people code their pages
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:27): although that has shifted towards other browsers now
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (13:33): oh well, after the coming apocalypse I guess someone can redesign the web from scratch, and get it right
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:34): The same people who designed the apocalypse, no doubt
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:34): once we get perfect humans, sure
